Subjective: Back pain, worsening 1.5 weeks. Radiates down right leg (posterior thigh, lateral lower leg) to foot. Pain all day, severe, prevents sleep. Started with lifting heavy objects at work. Temporarily stopped working. Decreased sensation, dull feeling, tingling on outside of right lower leg. Pain limits movement, but strength preserved. No numbness/dysfunction in perianal/genital area. No bowel/bladder incontinence. No fever, cough, SOB, headache. No smoking/alcohol.
Objective: Appears in pain on movement, e.g., getting onto couch, lifting right leg. No visual abnormalities of back or legs. No vertebral tenderness. Normal reflexes bilaterally. Leg strength preserved bilaterally. Sensation subjectively duller on right lower leg/foot compared to left.
Assessment: Lumbar disc herniation, likely compressing right sciatic nerve root. Nerve pain with sensory changes (paresthesia, altered sensation). No red flags for cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: Start Pregabalin for nerve pain, titrate dose slowly.
Advised not to drive when starting/titrating medication or if experiencing side effects.
Recommend physiotherapy for exercises to decompress nerve.
Pain relief may take weeks to months.
No immediate need for imaging (CT/MRI) or surgery.
Safety netting: Contact GP/clinic if worsening pain, loss of sensation in 'riding breeches' area, new bowel/bladder dysfunction, or significant leg weakness.
Telephone follow-up in 1 week to assess pain control.
